ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 111 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 111 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: This course is an overview of rational choice, game theory, electoral politics, and strategic decision making. It explores real-life examples like the 2016 election season, the Cuban Missile Crisis, and coordinating meet-up times/locations with friends. Professor Svolik is exceptionally coherent and delivers lectures that solidify your understanding of the topic, even if you did not do the reading. But the readings are fascinating, relevant, and absolutely necessary if you intend to leave the course with a solid understanding of how decisions are made democratically and strategically. Professor Svolik is also very accessible and genuinely cares about his students take this class!
Great course and prof. Learned so much. Svolik elevates teaching to a new level.
A great course for anyone interested in politics or game theory. The course covered a large variety of topics and built the analytical tools to evaluate other scenarios. A great fifth class!
Good class, not overwhelmingly difficult. I would recommend as a good introduction to game theory.
I definitely recommend this course. It has some very interesting readings and the classes are interesting at the same time.
